<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.2 is: A for loop shall be well-formed.
The three clauses of a for statement are the:
1. First clause shall be empty or an expression whose set the value of the loop counter or define and intialize the loop counter.
2. Second clause shall be an expression that has no persistent side effects, and shall use the loop counter and optionally loop control flags, and shall not use any other object that is modified in the for loop body.
3.Third clause shall be an expression whose modify only the value of the loop counter, and shall not use objects that are modified in the for loop body.
4. There shall only be one loop counter in a for loop, which shall not be modified in for loop body. A loop control flag is defined as single identifier denoting an object with Boolean type that is used in the second clause. The behaviour of a for loop body includes the behaviour of any functions called within that statement. 
</misra_rule>

<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_linux_bus_finish:
```c
void metal_linux_bus_finish(void)
{
	struct linux_bus *lbus;
	struct metal_bus *bus;

	for_each_linux_bus(lbus) {
		if (metal_bus_find(lbus->bus_name, &bus) == 0)
			metal_bus_unregister(bus);
	}
}
```

explanation: Only fragments that affect whether the for loop is well-formed (the loop clauses and any objects used by those clauses that may be modified in the loop body) are reported. The macro that expands to the for(...) is reported because it defines the loop clauses; the loop usage and its body (metal_bus_find / metal_bus_unregister) are reported because they form the loop behaviour and may modify objects accessed in the loop condition. The struct definitions for linux_bus and metal_bus are reported because they show that the loop condition accesses members of an object (bus_name / embedded metal_bus) that may be modified by the loop body. Other parts of the function (local variable declarations, function signature, braces, and unrelated struct members) do not affect whether the for loop clauses are well-formed under Rule 14.2 and therefore do not need investigation.
